articles.headline: Pakistan Uses Tribal Militias in Taliban War
articles.snippet: The use of tribal militias is a new tool for the Pakistani Army, which has met resistance from militants.
articles.abstract: The use of tribal militias is a new tool for the Pakistani Army, which has met resistance from militants.
articles.lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  Two tribal elders lay stretched out in an orthopedic ward here last week, their plastered limbs and winces of pain grim evidence of the slaughter they survived when a suicide bomber blew himself up in the midst of their tribal gathering.
articles.byline: By Jane Perlez and Pir Zubair Shah

articles.headline: In China, Steps to Ease Mortgages as Real Estate Loses Its Sizzle
articles.snippet: Fearing a surge in loan defaults for banks, the Chinese government announced a series of measures to support real estate prices.
articles.abstract: Fearing a surge in loan defaults for banks, the Chinese government announced a series of measures to support real estate prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHENZHEN, China  China’s real estate bubble has lost its fizz in many cities, complicating the government’s effort to manage an economic slowdown here.

articles.headline: New Life for the Death Tax
articles.snippet: The death tax, as its opponents call it, will live on. The shape of it, and its ability to raise significant sums from the very wealthy, will be decided by Congress next year.
articles.abstract: The death tax, as its opponents call it, will live on. The shape of it, and its ability to raise significant sums from the very wealthy, will be decided by Congress next year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Perhaps the greatest public relations coup of this decade was the successful persuasion of millions of Americans that repealing the estate tax was a populist cause. A tax that applied to a tiny handful of estates of wealthy people was relaxed and is now slated for repeal in 2010.

articles.headline: U.S. Vows More Help for Homeowners
articles.snippet: The government said it would help homeowners by insuring against losses on some modified loans.
articles.abstract: The government said it would help homeowners by insuring against losses on some modified loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: With foreclosures mounting, Bush administration officials said Thursday that they were preparing to step up efforts to help struggling homeowners.

articles.headline: West Is in Talks on Credit to Aid Poorer Nations
articles.snippet: With the financial crisis engulfing developing countries, Western officials are weighing coordinated action.
articles.abstract: With the financial crisis engulfing developing countries, Western officials are weighing coordinated action.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the financial crisis engulfing developing countries from Latin America to Central Europe, raising the specter of market panic and even social unrest, Western officials are weighing coordinated action to try to stabilize these economies.

articles.headline: Tight Credit Curbs Growth in India
articles.snippet: The country had little exposure to subprime lending or to Western financial institutions, but the government is pulling out all its tools to combat the global financial turmoil.
articles.abstract: The country had little exposure to subprime lending or to Western financial institutions, but the government is pulling out all its tools to combat the global financial turmoil.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI  Customers come in a tiny trickle to the showroom of Uppal Motors, a Honda motorcycle dealership near here in an upscale satellite of India’s capital.

articles.headline: Financial Crisis Spreads to Emerging Nations
articles.snippet: Once again, South Korea appears threatened by an international financial contagion that began elsewhere.
articles.abstract: Once again, South Korea appears threatened by an international financial contagion that began elsewhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — As the global financial crisis has unfolded, many South Koreans feel they are reliving a nightmare.

articles.headline: Group’s Tally of New Voters Was Vastly Overstated
articles.snippet: Republicans have seized on the disclosure that 30 percent of Acorn’s registrations were faulty.
articles.abstract: Republicans have seized on the disclosure that 30 percent of Acorn’s registrations were faulty.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Oct. 6, the community organizing group Acorn and an affiliated charity called Project Vote announced with jubilation that they had registered 1.3 million new voters. But it turns out the claim was a wild exaggeration, and the real number of newly registered voters nationwide is closer to 450,000, Project Vote’s executive director, Michael Slater, said in an interview.
articles.byline: By Michael Falcone and Michael Moss

articles.headline: In McCain’s Uphill Battle, Winning Is an Option
articles.snippet: Given the question marks hovering over the race, some observers argue John McCain still has a path to victory.
articles.abstract: Given the question marks hovering over the race, some observers argue John McCain still has a path to victory.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI  Senator John McCain woke Thursday morning to what has become a fairly common greeting in these tough last weeks of his campaign. A raft of polls showing him well behind. Early post-mortems on his candidacy. Even Republicans speaking of him in the past tense.

articles.headline: OPEC Says It Will Cut Oil Output
articles.snippet: OPEC ordered a cut in production of at least 1.5 million barrels a day, but a benchmark price dropped further.
articles.abstract: OPEC ordered a cut in production of at least 1.5 million barrels a day, but a benchmark price dropped further.
articles.lead_paragraph: VIENNA  Stung by what it called “a dramatic collapse” in crude prices, the OPEC cartel said on Friday that it would reduce output by a steeper-than-expected 1.5 million barrels a day. But that action failed to brake the price decline, and oil dropped 5 percent more by the end of the day.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Jad Mouawad
